facts: First discovered in 1889 by Othniel Charles Marsh
Had a large bony frill at the back of its head
Could weigh up to 12 tons
One of the largest carnivorous dinosaurs
Had teeth up to 8 inches long
Lived around 68 to 66 million years ago
Ankylosaurus had a heavily armored body covered in bony plates and spikes.
It had a large club-like structure at the end of its tail for defense.
Ankylosaurus lived during the Late Cretaceous period, approximately 68 to 66 million years ago.
Brachiosaurus had a long neck that was longer than its tail, allowing it to reach high vegetation.
It was one of the largest dinosaurs, reaching lengths of up to 80-85 feet and heights of up to 40-50 feet.
Brachiosaurus lived during the Late Jurassic period, about 154 to 150 million years ago.
Stegosaurus is famous for its distinctive row of large, bony plates along its back.
It had spikes on its tail known as the 'thagomizer' for defense.
Despite its large size, Stegosaurus had a relatively small brain compared to its body size.
Elasmosaurus had an extraordinarily long neck with up to 71 vertebrae, making up about half of its body length.
It was a marine reptile, not a dinosaur, that lived during the Late Cretaceous period, around 80 million years ago.
Elasmosaurus likely preyed on fish and other small marine animals.
Pteranodon was a pterosaur, a flying reptile, not a dinosaur.
Some species of Pteranodon had wingspans of up to 33 feet, making them one of the largest known flying reptiles.
It primarily fed on fish and likely used its long, toothless beak to catch prey.
All birds are living dinosaurs.
